author: By Zanna Sloniowska
title: I Left Ukraine 20 Years Ago. But It Never Left Me.
description: Departure, however final it seems, is not forever.
content: KRAKOW, Poland — A few years ago, after I gave a talk in a small Polish town, an old man sidled up to the table where I sat. “In what language do you dream?” he asked. “In all the languages I speak,” I answered honestly (I’m basically trilingual). “You are a person,” he replied with a slight note of condemnation, “without identity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: The War in Ukraine Puts America’s Problems in Perspective
description: Something for histrionic critics here at home to consider.
content: Heartbroken over what the Russian regime is currently doing to the nation of Ukraine, I can’t help finding myself thinking also of ways we’re taught to think about ourselves as a nation. Perhaps strangely, while I find myself sifting through the grim news of recent days, looking for signs of hope for Ukraine’s future, I also think of hope as it applies to matters here at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilya Somin
title: How the U.S. Can Help Refugees (and Weaken Vladimir Putin)
description: Opening our doors would ease the suffering caused by Vladimir Putin’s invasion and strengthen our position against him.
content: The United Nations reports that at least 1.5 million refugees have fled the fighting in Ukraine. Sadly, that figure is likely to grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: How Maori Stepped In to Save a Towering Tree Crucial to Their Identity
description: Tāne Mahuta, an ancient tree named after the god of forests in Māori mythology, is threatened by the slow creep of an incurable disease.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — In an ancient grove in northern New Zealand, the mighty conifer known as Tāne Mahuta, lord of the forest, is threatened by the encroachment of a deadly enemy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
title: Moldovans Welcome Fleeing Ukrainians, but Some Pack Their Own Bags, Too
description: Moldova has taken in more Ukrainians, per capita, than any other country. But the closer Russian troops get to Moldova, the more locals consider their own escape plans.
content: PURCARI, Moldova — Angela Dragan, a chef at a famous Moldovan winery, has spent the past two weeks making food for the exodus of refugees fleeing the invasion in neighboring Ukraine, and has hosted at least 10 of them in her home. There but for the grace of God, she reckons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Makes a Good Impression
description: Mary Lou Guizzo’s puzzle celebrates brilliance.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Well, this puzzle certainly makes a good impression! This is Mary Lou Guizzo’s 29th New York Times Crossword puzzle, and her veteran constructing chops are definitely on display. As the theme clues indicate, it honors a series of Nobelists who share a certain trait that should become clear as the puzzle comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: ‘Peaky Blinders’ Is Ending, but Its Fans Aren’t Done Just Yet
description: In Britain, where the final season is airing, the crime drama has a dedicated fan base who love to bring (certain) elements of the show to life.
content: LONDON — When Roy Short, John Brophy and Ryan Hyland dress up as Peaky Blinders, they do it properly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Marina Harss
title: Ukrainian Dancers Find Shelter Abroad as War Rages at Home
description: Opera houses and theaters in European cities are offering to help fleeing or stranded ballet dancers, even as many are still stuck in Ukraine.
content: PARIS — When Ivan Kozlov landed in France with the Kyiv City Ballet on Feb. 23, the drumbeat of a possible Russian attack on Ukraine was growing louder. But he still didn’t think that President Vladimir V. Putin’s forces would invade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker
title: The Long Shadow of Sandy Hook
description: In a persuasive and heartbreaking new book, Elizabeth Williamson argues that the 2012 shooting in Newtown, Conn., ushered in a new era of American conspiracy theories.
content: So we’re living in a world where, according to several polls, the majority of Republican voters believe Joe Biden stole the 2020 election, and some 41 million Americans are said to believe in QAnon. The rest of us, meanwhile, are struggling to explain when, precisely, our politics became so detached from reality. Some look to the propagandistic Clinton-hating conspiracies of the 1990s as the moment things started to change. Others blame the 9/11 truthers, or the original autism-related anti-vaccine panic. In her persuasive and heartbreaking new book, Elizabeth Williamson points to the horrific mass shooting in Newtown, Conn., on Dec. 14, 2012, when 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School were killed, and then a host of internet trolls set out to convince the world it didn’t happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Smithsonian to Return Most of Its Benin Bronze Collection to Nigeria
description: The Smithsonian has 39 of the West African artifacts in its possession. The move comes as the museum is reviewing its collection practices.
content: The Smithsonian Institution, one of the world’s largest cultural organizations, said on Tuesday that it planned to return most of its collection of Benin Bronzes to Nigeria, a sweeping move that would punctuate a monthslong institutional review of its collection practices and the ethics behind them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery, Emma Goldberg and Erin Woo
title: Rising Gas Prices Have Drivers Asking, ‘Is This for Real?’
description: The average price of a gallon of gasoline is up more than 10 percent in the last week, leading some consumers to rethink their routines and spending.
content: After months of working from home, Caroline McNaney, 29, was excited about going back to work in an office, even if her new job in Trenton, N.J., meant commuting an hour each way.
source.name: The New York Times

title: For this border crisis, Poles extend a warm welcome, unlike last time.
description: Hundreds of thousands of Polish families have opened their homes to refugees from Ukraine, a sharp contrast to the country’s response to a different crisis last fall at the border with Belarus.
content: On the morning after Russia invaded Ukraine, Maria Hawranek did what hundreds of thousands of Poles would soon do: She signed up to host refugees at her home in Krakow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Katie Glueck
title: Socialists’ Response to War in Ukraine Has Put Some Democrats on Edge
description: The Democratic Socialists of America’s view that U.S. “imperialist expansionism” through NATO fueled Russia’s invasion has created challenges for politicians aligned with the group.
content: Not long after Russia invaded Ukraine, the Democratic Socialists of America released a statement that drew instant reproof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames and Jonathan Abrams
title: Brittney Griner’s Impact Is Clear as W.N.B.A. Fans Await Word From Russia
description: Griner, one of the world’s best basketball players, was believed to have been detained in Russia on what customs officials described as drug charges. Fans are worried.
content: When Brittney Griner is on the basketball court, everyone knows. At 6-foot-9, she towers over most other players. She snatches rebounds over her opponents’ outstretched arms, and her teammates know the surest way to score: Deliver the ball to her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reggaeton’s Global Expansion and Wide-Open Future
description: As the genre grows in worldwide popularity, it is engaging with the pop music mainstream and stratifying into subsets, introducing new opportunities and dilemmas.
content: The current generation of reggaeton superstars — J Balvin, Rauw Alejandro, Farruko and more — find themselves in constant dialogue with pop, EDM and hip-hop, and have become ambitious ambassadors of cultural exchange. As the genre is growing in global popularity, it is also stratifying into subsets, some leaning toward the synthetic and some returning to roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: As Russia’s Military Stumbles, Its Adversaries Take Note
description: President Vladimir Putin could still reduce cities in Ukraine to rubble, officials say. But European countries say they are not as intimidated by Russian ground forces as they were in the past.
content: CONSTANTA, Romania — When it comes to war, generals say that “mass matters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: The Chicago teachers’ union vows to fight a plan to lift a school mask mandate.
description: Chicago Public Schools has announced plans to lift a mask requirement in the third-largest U.S. school district starting next week, infuriating members of the teachers’ union who stopped reporting to school buildings for a week in January to demand additional Covid-19 safeguards.
content: Chicago Public Schools has announced plans to lift a mask requirement in the third-largest U.S. school district starting next week, infuriating members of the teachers’ union who stopped reporting to school buildings for a week in January to demand additional Covid-19 safeguards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Another Marathon Day Ends With No M.L.B. Agreement
description: A 162-game season is back on the table, but so is the possibility of canceling more games. The sides will reconvene Wednesday morning.
content: Seven days after Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred canceled a week of regular season games because the league didn’t have a labor agreement with players in place to start the 2022 season, M.L.B. gave the players’ union a new deadline, with a slightly different position than before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google is buying Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm, for $5.4 billion.
description: The deal is intended to help Google differentiate its cloud business from that of its rivals Amazon and Microsoft.
content: Google announced one of its largest acquisitions on Tuesday, paying roughly $5.4 billion for the cybersecurity company Mandiant, a provider of services that help businesses prepare for and respond to cyberattacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Karen Zraick
title: Central Park Brush Fires May Have Been Deliberately Set, Officials Say
description: A series of fires in the park’s North Woods section were extinguished without injuries or serious damage.
content: A series of brush and trash fires in a wooded area of Central Park that blanketed the Manhattan sky with thick smoke Tuesday appeared to have been deliberately set, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden bans U.S. imports of Russian oil and natural gas, and Britain vows to phase Russian oil out.
description: The British also said they would phase out imports of Russian oil by the end of the year to increase the economic isolation of Russia’s president, Vladimir. V. Putin.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said Tuesday that the United States was punishing Russia for a “vicious war of choice” in Ukraine by banning importation of the country’s oil, gas and coal, but warned Americans that the decision would inevitably mean painful, higher prices for energy and at the gas pump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Prince Andrew Has Paid Settlement to Virginia Giuffre, Her Lawyer Says
description: A request for dismissal, approved by a judge on Tuesday, resolved a suit that accused Andrew of sexually abusing Ms. Giuffre when she was 17.
content: A lawsuit accusing Prince Andrew, the disgraced second son of Queen Elizabeth II and a former friend of the notorious sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, of raping Virginia Giuffre when she was a teenager was dismissed by a federal judge on Tuesday, following a request from both parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Tseng
title: In the Foothills of Los Angeles, a Celebration of Renewal
description: The Opening Ceremony founders Humberto Leon and Carol Lim closed out Lunar New Year with a dinner among friends in the glow of a full moon.
content: Since 2002, Humberto Leon and Carol Lim have run their trendsetting label Opening Ceremony more like a social club than a clothing line. “People often come to the brand through an event or a party we throw,” says Lim from the patio of Chifa, a 1980s-inflected Chinese Peruvian restaurant, with zebra-print walls and a big heart-shaped picture window, that Leon designed with the architect Michael Loverich. It’s a cool mid-February evening on the 15th and final day of Lunar New Year celebrations, and the pair’s loved ones have gathered in the glow of a full moon, in the cozy, vibrant Los Angeles neighborhood of Eagle Rock, to observe the Lantern Festival, a closing ceremony of sorts that symbolizes rebirth and promotes good fortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Rojas
title: Speaking in Tongues: Novels in Translation From Around the World
description: A South Korean female assassin, an Italian child of deaf parents, an intercaste marriage in Tamil Nadu.
content: THE OLD WOMAN WITH THE KNIFE By Gu Byeong-mo Translated by Chi-Young Kim 280 pp. Hanover Square. $19.99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Do You Invest in the Face of an Apocalypse?
description: Market strategists try to make sense of once-unthinkable scenarios.
content: A turbulent start to the week saw stock markets fall around the world, with the S&P 500 recording its sharpest daily decline since October 2020, while the Nasdaq and Germany’s benchmark index slipped into bear markets. Investors and analysts are assessing the latest developments in the war in Ukraine, revising their forecasts to take account of everything from commodity supply shortages (more on that below) to President Vladimir Putin of Russia putting his nuclear forces on alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Skewers Trump for a ‘Looney’ Idea on Russia
description: Meyers said the former president’s suggestion that the U.S. paint Chinese flags on planes and bomb Russia was “a slightly stupider version of Bugs Bunny dressing up as a sexy lady to distract Elmer Fudd.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: McDonald’s, Coca-Cola and Starbucks temporarily stop sales in Russia.
description: Pressure has been ramping up on the American brands to pull out of Russia.
content: After days of silence and seeming reluctance to take a stance while facing rising pressure to respond to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, several iconic American food and beverage companies said on Tuesday that they were pausing operations in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: concoction
description: This word has appeared in 65 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word concoction has appeared in 65 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 3 in “Attention, New Englanders: Fluffernutter Is Now a Word” by Carla Correa:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Foner
title: The Hidden Story of the North’s Victory in the Civil War
description: Roger Lowenstein’s “Ways and Means” offers a fresh perspective on the Civil War by explaining the importance of financing.
content: WAYS AND MEANSLincoln and His Cabinet and the Financing of the Civil WarBy Roger Lowenstein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Ban on Russian Oil Could Hit the U.S. Economy as Gas Prices Rise
description: The White House is stopping Russian energy imports as the country wages war on Ukraine, which could push American gas prices even higher.
content: The ban on Russian oil imports announced by President Biden on Tuesday could have meaningful consequences for the U.S. economy, pushing prices at the gas pump higher when inflation is already rapid, although how long-lasting that impact might be remains uncertain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How the Putin Shock Might Affect the World Economy
description: Will it be as bad as many people seem to think?
content: When Vladimir Putin invaded Ukraine, I think it’s fair to say that most observers expected him to get away with it. Surely Russia’s huge military would take Kyiv and other major cities within a few days; surely the West would respond with its usual timidity, giving Russia no more than a minor slap on the wrist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: On a Dirt Court, a Ravaged School Planted the Seeds of a Championship
description: A Louisiana high school lost its gym when a hurricane tore through town. Practicing on a dirt court, the girls’ basketball team adopted a defiant motto: No gym, no problem.
content: HICKS, La. — For the first time in months, there was no need to scramble for a place to practice basketball on Monday at Hicks High School. Not on the dirt court on its campus. Not at a Pentecostal church half an hour away. Not at a rival school 15 miles down the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Apple unveils a new iPhone, a new iPad and other devices.
description: In a showcase on Tuesday, Apple added to its ever-expanding array of product offerings.
content: Apple’s latest product showcase on Tuesday had all the hallmarks of a typical launch for the world’s most valuable public company: vibrant colors, upbeat music, a slate of incremental product improvements and a surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Battlefield reports are murky, but signs of Ukraine’s successes emerge.
description: The Ukrainian military claims to have killed thousands of Russian soldiers and destroyed hundreds of tanks and aircraft. Verifying the figures is challenging.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — With Russia and Ukraine engaged in an information war that is at times as intense as the clashes on the battlefield, attempts to capture losses and victories by either side are obscured by the fog of conflict and the work of powerful propaganda machines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Moderna opens the door to enforcing its vaccine patents in some countries.
description: The company had previously pledged not to enforce its Covid vaccine patents anywhere during the pandemic.
content: In the fall of 2020, just before Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine was found to be highly effective, the company pledged not to enforce patents on its vaccine during the pandemic. The company described the pledge as an effort to help hasten the end of the crisis, and it earned Moderna good will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Ghislaine Maxwell Juror Says He ‘Didn’t Lie’ to Get on Jury
description: The man’s statements to the news media after Ms. Maxwell’s conviction have clouded the guilty verdict in the case.
content: A juror whose failure to disclose that he was sexually abused as a child has clouded Ghislaine Maxwell’s conviction testified on Tuesday that he had made an “honest mistake” and had withheld the information inadvertently during the jury selection process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Goodbye New Zealand, Hello World
description: A changing of the guard at Musket Room, in NoLIta, brings border-hopping dishes that are worth putting on pants for.
content: The news that Matt Lambert, the chef who made Musket Room a lonely outpost of New Zealand cuisine in NoLIta, had been replaced by Mary Attea in February 2020 did not exactly echo throughout the land. At least, I didn’t hear about it. Then the engine fell out of the restaurant economy a few weeks later, and details like changes of kitchen leadership seemed even less urgent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: W.H.O. condemns attacks on health care services in Ukraine and calls for safe passage for medical supplies.
description: The organization has confirmed at least 16 attacks on the medical system, which is facing urgent supply shortages.
content: With the health care system in Ukraine facing urgent supply shortages, the head of the World Health Organization’s European region on Tuesday condemned attacks on health services and underscored the need for a humanitarian passage to deliver equipment and medicine to the hardest-hit regions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A San Francisco Renovation Inspired by ‘American Gigolo’
description: When an interior designer and a software engineer set about renovating their new house, they had no idea what it would ultimately involve.
content: Like many new homeowners, Kevin Sawyers and Peter Steinauer knew they wanted to make some changes when they bought a house in the Dolores Heights neighborhood of San Francisco in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Donadio
title: A French Feminist Tells Us to Embrace Our Inner Hag
description: “In Defense of Witches,” Mona Chollet’s exploration of the life and times of a polarizing archetype, was a divisive best seller in her native France.
content: IN DEFENSE OF WITCHESThe Legacy of the Witch Hunts and Why Women Are Still on TrialBy Mona CholletTranslated by Sophie R. Lewis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Human Rights Chief to Visit China
description: Michelle Bachelet would be the first official in her position to visit China, which has come under fire for its rights record, in nearly two decades.
content: GENEVA — The United Nations’ top human rights official said on Tuesday that China would allow her to visit the country and examine conditions there, including in the Xinjiang region, a startling twist after years of negotiations and stonewalling by Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Do You Feel About U.S. Mask Mandates Lifting?
description: We want to hear from you.
content: Mask mandates are quickly being lifted across the United States as Omicron cases have receded and Covid-19 deaths have fallen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Chattanooga’s Buzzer-Beater Comes With Something Extra
description: Overtime? Check. Game on the line? Check. N.C.A.A. tournament at stake? Check.
content: March has a reputation for delivering big plays in college basketball. But there has seldom been a play that checked as many boxes of excitement as the one by the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga men’s basketball team against Furman University on Monday night in Asheville, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: This Sedative Is Now a Go-To Drug for Executions. But Does It Work?
description: A legal battle in Oklahoma over whether prisoners feel severe pain after being given the sedative, midazolam, will determine whether its use is constitutional.
content: The status of executions across the country has been in turmoil for more than a decade, ever since pharmaceutical companies began halting their delivery of the most widely used drugs for executions. State prison systems were left to create cocktails of the drugs they could still get their hands on, often relying on one sedative in particular, midazolam, to start the execution process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Calendar Girl’ Review: A Portrait of an Angel of Fashion
description: This documentary follows Ruth Finley to shows and tributes as she reluctantly brings her decades-long career to a close.
content: Fashion is a cosmos unto itself, as so many books, articles and films insist on reminding us. And so it has its own angels and demons — as you know, the Devil wears Prada. In this firmament, Ruth Finley, who died in 2018 at the age of 98, was unquestionably one of the angels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Cabaret,’ Starring Eddie Redmayne, Leads Olivier Award Nominees
description: A revival of the 1966 musical, with Jessie Buckley as Sally Bowles, is up for 11 awards at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
content: LONDON — A revival of “Cabaret” that has been a topic of conversation here for its sky-high ticket prices as much as its stellar cast dominated the nominations for this year’s Olivier Awards — Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys — that were announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why So Many Billionaires Live in California
description: Blame Silicon Valley.
content: Of the 100 wealthiest people in America, 26 live in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: It’s ‘Alarming’: Children Are Severely Behind in Reading
description: The fallout from the pandemic is just being felt. “We’re in new territory,” educators say.
content: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — The kindergarten crisis of last year, when millions of 5-year-olds spent months outside of classrooms, has become this year’s reading emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Gearhart
title: An Olympic marathoner’s journey from Kenya to the front lines in Ukraine.
description: Mykola Nyzhnyk was training in Kenya, the world’s distance running hotbed, when he was called up to fight in the war.
content: ITEN, Kenya — The Ukrainian marathoner Mykola Nyzhnyk was asleep in the Kenyan countryside on Feb. 24 when he received a call from his pregnant wife, Olga. Alone in their apartment in Brovary, roughly 13 miles from Kyiv, she’d heard two explosions, so strong that the windows were shaking, she said. Ten minutes later, a third blast drowned out the piercing siren of car alarms, and she described a growing cloud of smoke in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Mel’s, Wood-Fired Pizza From a Former Del Posto Chef, Opens
description: An outpost of Katsuya in the Citizens New York food hall, a casual new addition of Serafina, and more restaurant news.
content: Fitted snugly to one side of the former Del Posto, the narrow restaurant space that was once John Dory is now a pizzeria: Mel’s, the first restaurant of a new food complex here. The name refers to the former Del Posto and Daniel chef Melissa J. Rodriguez, who is partnering with Jeff Katz and James Kent of Crown Shy and Saga to develop this sprawling space. (Al Coro, a lavish Italian restaurant, and Discolo, a lower-level lounge, will open in the Del Posto space in early summer.) Mel’s is done warmly in orange tones and polished light wood, a bar and a dining counter open into a rear dining room, and a huge wood-fired pizza oven is central to the space. “Everything is cooked with wood,” Ms. Rodriguez said. “There’s no gas here.” The pizzas start with Margherita but quickly veer into creative territory: mushrooms, smoked mozzarella and shaved shallots; and kale, basil pesto, ricotta and preserved lemon. Many appetizers, like roasted parsnips with robiola cheese, roasted maitake mushrooms with soppressata piccante, and charred shrimp, are wood fired, as are mains like whole fish, whole roasted cauliflower and strip steak. Unlike at most pizzerias, dessert is neither an afterthought nor skippable. Consider milk chocolate gelato with dark chocolate sable swirl; salted caramel and fior di latte gelato with caramel sauce and shortbread crumble; or an Italian rainbow cookie hot fudge sundae, a tribute to Little Italy. The timing of the opening is calculated so that Ms. Rodriguez, a Culinary Institute of America graduate, has several months to get Mel’s in order before Al Coro is unveiled. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Military Giant Proves Clumsy. Rivals Notice.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 8, 2022.
content: “The Kremlin spent the last 20 years trying to modernize its military. Much of that budget was stolen and spent on mega-yachts in Cyprus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: How Does Your Body React to Stress?
description: Tell us what you’ve noticed and how you deal with it.
content: What happens to your body when you’re stressed? Do your shoulders become tense? Does your stomach roil? Do you get headaches or back pain? Can you sleep? By contrast, how does your body feel when you are calm and more carefree? Is there a big difference?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Better.com, a mortgage lender and early pandemic winner, announces more layoffs.
description: The company will let go more than 3,000 employees three months after gaining notoriety for firing 900 workers in a Zoom call.
content: Better.com, the mortgage lending company, plans to fire more than a third of its staff this week, the company said on Tuesday, three months after its chief executive, Vishal Garg, set off an outcry by firing more than 900 employees on a Zoom call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Holly Golightly, Hypebeast
description: Givenchy makes pearls for tough girls at Paris Fashion Week.
content: There’s a lot to see at fashion week. Blink (or scroll too fast) and you’ll miss the details: feathered bags, futuristic sunglasses, fork jewelry. All month long, we’ll spotlight the things we saw that surprised or delighted us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Fiona Hill on the War Putin Is Really Fighting
description: A discussion on the Russian president’s motivations, the West’s response and how the conflict could play out.
content: Vladimir Putin was looking for a swift invasion that would halt Ukraine’s drift toward the West, reveal NATO’s fractures and weaknesses and solidify Russia as a global power. In response, the West threatened moderate sanctions, but ultimately showed little interest in stepping between Russia and Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Fiona Hill
description: A conversation with Fiona Hill,  former senior director for European and Russian affairs at the National Security Council.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Fiona Hill. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Eshe Nelson
title: Stocks fall again and energy prices climb as the West plans new barriers for Russian oil.
description: Gas prices hit a record in the United States. Stocks on Wall Street fell for their fourth consecutive day.
content: Stocks on Wall Street fell again and oil and gas prices surged on Tuesday as Western governments advanced efforts to isolate Russia by taking steps to cut it off from global oil markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Louis Vuitton’s Teenage Dream
description: And Stella McCartney’s artistic adulting. Designers go on a tour through the ages.
content: PARIS — Fashion’s fetish for youth is the Gordian knot at its center: often the very generation that obsesses about it most is the one least likely to be able to afford to wear it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Ephrat Livni
title: Reality Intrudes on a Utopian Crypto Vision
description: The cryptocurrency boom has spawned enterprises democratically governed by a community of users. Or that’s the theory. Making it work has been much messier.
content: WASHINGTON — American CryptoFed is a new kind of company spawned by the advent of cryptocurrency — one that claims, in a way, not to be a company at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Granville, Eshe Nelson and Stanley Reed
title: Shell says it will quit purchasing oil and gas from Russia.
description: The oil giant said it would immediately halt spot purchases of Russian oil, but described other measures as a “phased withdrawal” as it seeks alternative sources.
content: Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, said Tuesday it would begin withdrawing from its involvement “in all Russian hydrocarbons,” including an immediate halt to all spot purchases of Russian crude and the shuttering of its service stations in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Aaron Rodgers Says He Has a Deal to Stay With the Packers
description: The quarterback, a four-time N.F.L. most valuable player, had been locked in a conflict with the team over his influence in personnel decisions.
content: Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, a four-time N.F.L. most valuable player, has agreed to remain with the team, concluding his yearlong back-and-forth with the club about his future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: China’s Russia Problem
description: Things were going very well for China, until the war in Ukraine.
content: As China has emerged as a power over the past decade, it has benefited from the political disarray among its global rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe, Gaia Pianigiani and David D. Kirkpatrick
title: A 459-Foot Mystery in a Tuscan Port: Is It a Russian’s Superyacht?
description: As European authorities go after the luxury assets of oligarchs close to Vladimir Putin, a superyacht cloaked in secrecy has come under investigation.
content: From Germany’s North Sea ports to the French Riviera, open season has been declared on superyachts. Across Europe, authorities are hunting down luxury vessels tied to Russian oligarchs in the effort to inflict pain on President Vladimir V. Putin’s allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Juliet Macur
title: Grand Jury Appears Set to Weigh Charges Against Deshaun Watson
description: Women who filed sexual misconduct complaints against Watson, the Houston Texans quarterback, last year have been subpoenaed to give testimony on Friday in Houston, their lawyer said.
content: Nearly a year after allegations of sexual misconduct against Deshaun Watson were first publicized, several women who filed criminal complaints against him have been subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury on Friday, according to their lawyer, Tony Buzbee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Pentagon Will Close Hawaii Fuel Depot That Leaked Petroleum
description: A November leak at the fuel-storage facility contaminated drinking water, forcing more than 3,000 military families to leave their homes for temporary accommodation.
content: The United States military will permanently close a Navy fuel storage facility in Hawaii that leaked petroleum into the local drinking water supply last year, the Pentagon said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Chinese companies that aid Russia could face U.S. repercussions, commerce secretary warns.
description: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, said the U.S. could take “devastating” action against Chinese companies that defy Russian sanctions.
content: Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, issued a stern warning Tuesday to Chinese companies that might defy U.S. restrictions against exporting to Russia, saying the United States would cut them off from American equipment and software they need to make their products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: ‘Booth’ Pushes an Assassin Off Center Stage
description: In her new novel, Karen Joy Fowler imagines the lives of John Wilkes Booth’s troubled parents and his many siblings.
content: “Why did you do it, Johnny? Nobody agrees.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Search Begins for the Wreck Behind an Epic Tale of Survival’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how a team of modern adventurers are searching the icy Antarctic seas for Ernest Shackleton’s ship Endurance over 100 years after it was lost.
content: Featured Article: “A Search Begins for the Wreck Behind an Epic Tale of Survival” by Henry Fountain
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: Nobel Prize Winning Women in the Tuesday Crossword Puzzle
description: In more than 100 years, 943 people have won Nobel Prizes. Only 58 of them have been women.
content: Spoiler alert: This post will give away five answers in the Tuesday New York Times Crossword puzzle, constructed by Mary Lou Guizzo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: U.S. gas prices hit a high: $4.17 a gallon.
description: The price of a gallon of gas has climbed in the aftermath of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Russia is a major producer of oil.
content: Gas prices, which have been steadily rising for weeks as the conflict in Ukraine has escalated, hit a new high in the United States on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress Approves Legislation to Return the Postal Service to Solvency
description: The bill, the most sweeping overhaul of the agency in nearly two decades, now heads to President Biden’s desk for his signature.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress gave final approval on Tuesday to the most sprawling overhaul of the Postal Service in nearly two decades, sending President Biden legislation intended to return the beleaguered agency to solvency and address pandemic-era mail delays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: The Future Turns Dark for Russia’s Oil Industry
description: An exodus by Western companies and disdain for Russian oil signal the start of a reckoning.
content: A week after a chorus of Western executives from Exxon Mobil, BP, Shell and other companies denounced Moscow’s violent onslaught in Ukraine and pledged to pull their companies out of Russian ventures, it appears the turbulence for Russia’s energy industry has only begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: A Smithsonian zoo and museum are set to reopen seven days a week with masks optional.
description: The Smithsonian Institution says that it will expand some of its opening hours in the next week and no longer require visitors to wear a mask at its zoo and its nearly two dozen museums along the East Coast.
content: The Smithsonian Institution says that it will expand some of its opening hours in the next week and no longer require visitors to wear a mask at its zoo and its nearly two dozen museums along the East Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Masked or Maskless? Now New York Students Can Choose.
description: Schoolchildren and their parents had a range of views on the day that the mandate requiring masks in schools was lifted.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday, the second day that masks will be optional in New York City public schools. We’ll look at how things went on the first day. We’ll also see how Russian restaurants are faring as the war continues against Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Edmund Keeley Dies at 94; Shined a Light on Modern Greek Culture
description: The pre-eminent translator of poets like C.P. Cavafy and George Seferis, he was also a well-regarded novelist and poet in his own right.
content: Edmund Keeley, who as a novelist, translator, scholar and poet brought an appreciation of modern Greek literature and culture to the English-speaking world, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christie Aschwanden
title: How to Master the Pull-Up
description: The trick is to break the movement into pieces and train with patience and deliberateness.
content: I’ve always loved pull-ups, partly out of spite. There is a common fitness refrain that women can’t do them, and I don’t like to be told I can’t do something — especially if the reason is my gender. As a teenager, I pushed lawn-mowers and hauled rocks just to show that being a girl didn’t mean I was weak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Climate Hawks Join the Debate on Ukraine
description: Environmentalists say now is the time to choke off Russia’s oil and gas profits. But the White House has difficult choices to make.
content: In 2010, David Roberts, an influential left-leaning journalist and blogger, coined the term “climate hawk” to refer to activists pushing for aggressive solutions to the dangers of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Ukrainians Trying to Flee to U.K. Face a Confounding Path
description: The government has offered a way for U.K. residents to bring over Ukrainian relatives fleeing the war. But families and rights groups say it’s a bureaucratic nightmare that makes it too difficult to get in.
content: LONDON — Charlotte Shevchenko-Knight flipped through old family photo albums and toured the snowy neighborhoods of the Ukrainian capital when she visited her grandparents in Kyiv in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: The New York Times Pulls Its News Staff From Russia
description: Other news organizations, like Bloomberg, have suspended their operations in Russia in response to a new law that effectively criminalizes independent reporting.
content: The New York Times said on Tuesday that it was temporarily removing its journalists from Russia in the wake of harsh new legislation that effectively outlaws independent reporting on the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Former Proud Boys Leader Indicted in Jan. 6 Investigation
description: A federal grand jury charged Enrique Tarrio with conspiracy in the Capitol attack last year, making him the second leader of a far-right group to face charges in the past several months.
content: Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, was charged in a federal indictment unsealed on Tuesday with conspiring with other top lieutenants of the far-right nationalist group to disrupt the certification of the 2020 presidential election by helping to plan and launch the attack on the Capitol last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman, Julianne McShane, Nate Schweber and Lola Fadulu
title: Allowed to go maskless, some New York City students choose not to.
description: For the first time in two years, students in New York City were allowed to attend public school without masks on Monday, but some of them said they would keep them on.
content: For the first time in two years, students in New York City were allowed to attend public school without masks on Monday, but some of them said they would keep them on.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Really Didn’t Want to Hurt Her’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Durian. It’s love or hate with this fruit. In my family, only Grandma and I were fans. Because of its pungent odor, my family members with milder tastes made a house rule: Durian must be consumed in the parking lot or playground, never indoors. Indignant and banished, I found comfort in Grandma’s solidarity. Together, we’d wolf down the divisive fruit, reveling in its strong taste and frozen flesh. Now, whenever I feel outcast, my fellow durian warrior inspires courage. I remember looking up at Grandma, chowing down in Hong Kong’s sweltering heat with a satisfied smirk, honoring her own taste. — Jocelyn Ming Hei Chan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: New York’s Russian Restaurants Feel War’s Impact
description: Most owners are antiwar, and many of them are from Ukraine. But customer numbers are down all the same.
content: After Russia invaded Ukraine, Sveta, a small restaurant in the West Village known for its Instagram-friendly cocktails and hearty Russian fare like borscht, received a plethora of negative emails. One simply said, “Go Home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon Web Services blocks new sign-ups from Russia and Belarus.
description: The policy change for Amazon Web Services started over the weekend but was not publicly announced until Tuesday.
content: Amazon has quietly stopped letting customers in Russia and Belarus open new cloud computing accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Meet South Korea’s Swing Voters: Young, Broke and Angry
description: Frustrated over housing prices, a lack of job opportunities and a widening income gap, the once-reliable voting bloc is undecided and will most likely elect the next president.
content: Follow our live coverage of the presidential election in South Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Jones
title: Like Cheetahs, Ancient Ocean Creatures May Have Moved With a Gallop
description: Long before vertebrates moved to land, a study finds, some organisms moved with asymmetrical gaits.
content: Cheetahs are the fastest animals on land, clocking in at speeds over 60 miles per hour. Salamanders, in comparison, run at a far more measured pace. While cheetahs are exponentially larger and stronger than salamanders, another big difference between the two is how they move — their gait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Beyond Beyoncé Fame, Awol Erizku Expands What Black Art Can Be
description: With an exhibition at Gagosian, Erizku reaches a broad audience, and hopes he is seen as more than “a photographer for hire.”
content: LOS ANGELES — True, Awol Erizku may be best known for his beatific photograph of a pregnant ​​Beyoncé, which in 2017 was the most liked post in Instagram’s history. And Erizku has taken many other memorable images of celebrities, including the young inauguration poet Amanda Gorman for the cover of Time and the “Black Panther” actor Michael B. Jordan for GQ.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Where to Eat Great Lao Food Around Los Angeles
description: Find the deep, delicious flavors of this mighty Southeast Asian cuisine at these spots in the city and Orange County.
content: Lao food has been obscured in Southern California and all over the United States for too long, for a tangle of reasons. But a generation of Lao cooks is working to change this, with small food businesses and restaurants, social media campaigns and recipe videos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Rachelle Bonja, Chelsea Daniel, Rikki Novetsky, Patricia Willens, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Why Zelensky Poses a Unique Threat to Putin
description: As the war grinds on, Ukraine’s president is trying to reach out to Russian citizens — many of them remember him as a popular comedian.
content: Since the start of the war in Ukraine, no single figure has antagonized President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as effectively or persistently as President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Masking helped protect children from the virus last fall, a C.D.C. study suggests.
description: The study found that districts with full mask requirements had 23 percent lower rates of the coronavirus among students and staff members than districts without the mandates.
content: More and more American school districts have dropped mask mandates in recent weeks as coronavirus cases plunged across the United States. But they remain a subject of debate among some students and their parents, and a study released on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggested that those mandates had helped protect children and teachers from the coronavirus last fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Natalie Kitroeff and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Venezuela Releases Imprisoned Americans After Talks With U.S.
description: The release of Gustavo Cárdenas, an executive at the U.S. branch of Venezuela’s state oil company, and Jorge Alberto Fernández came after Biden officials moved to thaw relations with Venezuela, long a steadfast Russian ally.
content: Venezuela’s authoritarian government on Tuesday released at least two imprisoned Americans, a potential turning point in the Biden administration’s relationship with Russia’s staunchest ally in the Western Hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: He Spent $57,000 in Covid Relief on a Pokémon Card. Now the U.S. Owns It.
description: The mint Charizard trading card will be auctioned off with other fraudulently obtained luxury items seized by the U.S. Marshals. Its former owner was sentenced to three years in prison.
content: The forfeitures have included Lamborghinis, gold bars and luxury goods from Dior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: New York City’s students shed their masks, warily, in a pandemic milestone.
description: A kindergartner in Queens wasn’t quite ready to part with his Mickey Mouse masks. On Staten Island, another kindergartner had lost one of his bottom teeth and couldn’t wait to show off his new smile.
content: A kindergartner in Queens wasn’t quite ready to part with his Mickey Mouse masks. On Staten Island, another kindergartner had lost one of his bottom teeth and couldn’t wait to show off his new smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: As Fighting Gets Closer, a Kyiv Hospital Treats the War’s Atrocities
description: As Russian bombings have grown more indiscriminate, hospitals in Ukraine have become perilous places to work.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — A grim scene awaited Dr. Oleksandr Sherbina as he made the rounds of Clinical Hospital No. 7, a medical facility that once specialized in treating strokes but is now suddenly immersed in the atrocities of war. As he passed the operating theater, surgeons were amputating the lower leg of a wounded Ukrainian soldier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: At the Oscar Nominees Luncheon: Glamour, Griping and Gluten-Free Meals
description: At the annual event for nominees and their guests, everyone was happy to be meeting face to face, but the plan to pretape several awards on Oscar night was a sore subject.
content: LOS ANGELES — On Monday morning, as Daniel Ojari left the house to go to a luncheon for this year’s Oscar nominees, his 4-year-old son surprised him with a handwritten card.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pols
title: A Thriller Wrapped in a Story of Sisters and First Love
description: “Ocean State” is Stewart O’Nan’s latest addition to an oeuvre that specializes in family drama.
content: OCEAN STATEBy Stewart O’Nan240 pp. Atlantic Monthly Press. $27
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Homeland Security Dept. gathered millions of money transfer records, senator says.
description: Senator Ron Wyden asked the agency’s inspector general to open an investigation of the program, which involved four states and Mexico.
content: The Department of Homeland Security collected records on millions of money transfers between people in Mexico and four American states in what Senator Ron Wyden said amounted to a secret “bulk surveillance” program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Once Obscured in the U.S., Lao Cooks Share and Celebrate Their Cuisine
description: At times spicy and bitter, salty and pungent, herbaceous and sour — Lao food is intensely delicious.
content: LOS ANGELES — Ava Phengsy is a Lao home cook, but I also think of her as an artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Iran Nuclear Deal Nears Completion, but Russia Poses Complication
description: With the world eager to wean itself from Russian oil after the invasion of Ukraine, negotiators appeared close to signing a revived nuclear pact with Iran and lifting sanctions. Then Moscow put up a hurdle.
content: BRUSSELS — With negotiators all but finished with their work to restore the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran, the Russian invasion of Ukraine has made an agreement both more urgent and more difficult to get.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Review: In ‘Jane Anger,’ Revenge Is a Thorny Uphill Climb
description: Talene Monahon aims to give Shakespeare his comeuppance in this comedy at the New Ohio Theater.
content: In “Jane Anger,” a new comedy by Talene Monahon, everyone is fed up with the endless waves of sickness and quarantine. The year is 1606, and we are in England, which is enduring another outbreak of the plague. But for one man, a late-career William Shakespeare, there are graver concerns: writer’s block.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: An intensifying humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.
content: Increasingly indiscriminate Russian shelling that has trapped and traumatized Ukrainian civilians is magnifying fears of a humanitarian crisis. Tens of thousands have been left without food, water, power or heat in besieged cities of southern Ukraine and elsewhere. Follow the latest updates here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Suddenly, oil companies are upbeat again
description: Prices are soaring as industry leaders meet in Houston. The vibe at the conference is “we’re part of the solution.”
content: If you’ve been following climate news, you might feel a bit of vertigo at what I’m about to tell you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Sifferlin
title: It’s Been Two Years Since the Pandemic Began. Where Do We Go From Here?
description: Writers reflect on our lingering questions.
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Seahawks Plan to Trade Russell Wilson to the Broncos
description: Wilson led the Seattle Seahawks to back-to-back Super Bowl appearances, winning once, but had taken issue with being left out of personnel decisions.
content: Russell Wilson, the face of the Seattle Seahawks for the past decade, is expected to head to Denver as part of a multi-player trade with the Broncos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Madden
title: ‘Kony 2012,’ 10 Years Later
description: Once the most viral video of all time, the film reads as both a digital relic and a precursor to an era in which footage of conflict dominates the internet.
content: At the start of 2012, much of the world had never heard of Joseph Kony, a Central African warlord responsible, by UNICEF’s count, for abducting tens of thousands of children to enslave them and use them as soldiers, and for displacing more than 2.5 million people throughout the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
title: The Smugglers’ Paradise of Afghanistan
description: For decades, the smuggling trade — of people, drugs and money — has dominated Nimruz Province. Now, as hundreds of thousands of Afghans try to flee, business has further boomed for those who hold the keys to the gate.
content: ZARANJ, Afghanistan — The smuggler barreled down the narrow dirt road, bouncing into craters and over rocks that jutted out from the scrubland. His headlights were off and as the car picked up speed, he tightened his grip on the steering wheel trying to wrestle it under his control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu, Nate Schweber, Julianne McShane and Sadef Ali Kully
title: What Young New Yorkers Think About the End of the School Mask Mandate
description: Some students said they were excited to finally shed their masks, but others felt unsafe and wanted to continue wearing them.
content: New York City officials this week eliminated the mask mandate for public school students that had been in place since fall 2020, an aggressive step toward normalcy two years after the coronavirus began battering the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Fossil of Vampire Squid’s Oldest Ancestor Is Named for Biden
description: Scientists describe a new species of vampyropod from a 328-million-year-old, 10-armed fossil found in Montana.
content: About 328 million years ago, Fergus County, Mont., was no stranger to monsoons. Back then, the region was a marine bay, much like the Bay of Bengal in South Asia. The tropical storms regularly flushed the bay with freshwater and fine sediments, feeding algal blooms and depleting the water of oxygen in certain spots. Anything that died in these spots could have the rare posthumous luck of being preserved, undisturbed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Lululemon, which grew rapidly in pandemic, will soon offer shoes.
description: Lululemon plans to sell athletic footwear for women, underscoring its growth ambitions.
content: Lululemon, the athleisure brand that was a rare retail success story during the pandemic, said on Tuesday that it will begin selling athletic footwear for women this month, underscoring its growth ambitions and how it hopes to outfit its customers from head to toe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Finding a Retirement Home for 466 Frozen Flatworm Fragments
description: When researchers end their careers, where do their biological collections go?
content: Marian Litvaitis, a professor emerita at the University of New Hampshire, decided to retire in December 2019. And she wondered what would happen to her worms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Texas Youth Gender Clinic Closed Last Year Under Political Pressure
description: A Texas clinic for transgender adolescents closed last year amid pressure from the governor’s office, hospital officials said in phone recordings.
content: On a tense conference call last November with half a dozen doctors and executives at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dr. John Warner relayed a somber message: The only specialty clinic in the state to treat transgender adolescents was facing unrelenting political pressure to close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Minneapolis Teachers Begin Strike After Talks Fail
description: The union is asking for smaller class sizes and higher wages, while the school district says its budget is shrinking because of declining enrollment. After negotiations, St. Paul averted a strike.
content: Teachers in Minneapolis went on strike Tuesday morning, shuttering classrooms for about 30,000 public school students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Sixteen Years After ‘The Road,’ Cormac McCarthy Is Publishing Two New Novels
description: This fall, Knopf will publish two interlinked books that are a thematic and stylistic departure for the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist.
content: During a rare appearance in Santa Fe, N.M., in 2015, Cormac McCarthy offered a tantalizing glimpse of his work in progress: “The Passenger,” a novel that explored esoteric ideas about math, physics and the nature of consciousness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: The European Union seeks independence from Russian oil and gas.
description: Europe had long trusted in what many thought was a mutually beneficial business relationship. That has changed.
content: The European Commission on Tuesday outlined ambitious proposals to “make Europe independent from Russian fossil fuels well before 2030.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: U.S. Bans Russian Oil
description: McDonald’s and other big American brands are suspending operations in Russia.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Taste Test
description: Do you like trying new foods?
content: Are you adventurous when it comes to sampling new foods? Or are you a picky eater? Have you ever expected to hate the taste of something, only to discover a new favorite food? What is a memorable experience you’ve had with a new food?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Opportunities Did Covid Steal From You?
description: Tell us how the pandemic led you to miss opportunities, and what you’re doing to get them back.
content: The pandemic upended the global economy, shut down capitals and statehouses, and devastated businesses. But along with these major disruptions came smaller, more personal derailments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden Offers More Free Covid Tests Although Demand Has Slowed
description: The White House is now letting households order a second round of at-home coronavirus tests, saying that testing remains important even as cases plummet.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Tuesday formally began allowing Americans who had ordered free coronavirus tests this winter to request a second round of four tests per household, through the same U.S. Postal Service program that President Biden unveiled in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Bloomfield Cucchiara
title: Too Many Americans Don’t Understand What Happens in Their Schools
description: Why was the pandemic so disruptive to education?
content: PHILADELPHIA — As America enters a less acute phase of the Covid-19 pandemic, it is time to reflect upon what we lost and what we learned. America’s failure to prioritize time in school should be at the top of the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold
title: F.B.I. Sees ‘Massive Fraud’ in Groups’ Food Programs for Needy Children
description: Cracking down on the misuse of pandemic assistance, the agency says nonprofits in the Minneapolis area siphoned off tens of millions of dollars.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Last year, with the federal government making available huge new sums of money for programs to feed needy children during the pandemic, a nonprofit organization called Advance Youth Athletic Development set up what it described as an enormous child care operation in northeast Minneapolis that could prepare 5,000 dinners each weeknight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Conrad Janis, Father on ‘Mork & Mindy’ and Much More, Dies at 94
description: His role on the hit sitcom was just one of more than 100 film and television credits; he was also a fine jazz trombonist and co-owner of an art gallery.
content: Conrad Janis, an actor familiar to television viewers as Mindy’s father on the hit sitcom “Mork & Mindy” who was also a skilled jazz musician and a gallerist well known in the New York art world, died on March 1 in Los Angeles. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: PGA Tour Commissioner Has Strong Words for Phil Mickelson
description: “The ball is in his court,” Jay Monahan said of the golfer who is taking a break from competition after saying he supported a rival, Saudi-backed league.
content: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — In his first meeting with reporters since Phil Mickelson’s controversial remarks about offering assistance to an upstart Saudi-backed golf league, Jay Monahan, the PGA Tour commissioner, said on Tuesday that he had not talked with Mickelson but that he did not absolve him from future punishment for his comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Aaron Rodgers, fined by the N.F.L. over vaccination rules, says he will stay with the Packers.
description: Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, a four-time N.F.L. most valuable player, has agreed to remain with the team, concluding his yearlong back-and-forth with the club about his future.
content: Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, a four-time N.F.L. most valuable player, has agreed to remain with the team, concluding his yearlong back-and-forth with the club about his future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Companies stay in China despite political risks and travel limits.
description: Worries about pandemic restrictions and trade relations are growing, but most American companies say they have no plans to move operations to other countries, a new survey shows.
content: BEIJING — American companies are increasingly worried about coronavirus restrictions, regulatory issues and trade tensions with China, but have been cautious so far about moving production elsewhere, new figures show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Weight Watchers App Gathered Data From Children, F.T.C. Says
description: Kurbo by WW, a weight-loss app geared toward children, illegally collected data from users as young as 8 without their parents’ consent, the Federal Trade Commission said in a complaint.
content: WW International, the weight-loss organization formerly known as Weight Watchers, used an app to illegally collect personal information from children without their parents’ permission, the Federal Trade Commission said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: The Loophole That’s Fueling a Return to Teenage Vaping
description: Sales are rising of flavored e-cigarettes using synthetic nicotine that evades regulatory oversight, a gap that lawmakers are now trying to close.
content: The Food and Drug Administration’s crackdown on flavored e-cigarettes in 2020 was meant to be a comprehensive, aggressive strategy to curtail the epidemic of teenage vaping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Zelensky is seen in his office in Kyiv for the first time since invasion began.
description: The Ukrainian president told his people that he was not afraid or in hiding.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spoke from his office in Kyiv on Monday night, the first time he had been seen there since the Russian invasion began on Feb. 24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: U.S. mask mandates are lifting quickly, but there are notable exceptions.
description: Mask mandates have disappeared rapidly in the last few weeks in the United States as Omicron cases have receded. But some school districts, cities and one state are holding out, and some teachers, parents and students fear that dropping mask mandates in schools is premature.
content: Mask mandates have disappeared rapidly in the last few weeks in the United States as Omicron cases have receded. But some school districts, cities and one state are holding out, and some teachers, parents and students fear that dropping mask mandates in schools is premature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Texas Man Convicted in First Jan. 6 Trial
description: The guilty verdict against Guy Wesley Reffitt came as prosecutors expanded their investigation into the Capitol attack by indicting a former leader of the far-right group the Proud Boys.
content: A federal jury on Tuesday swiftly convicted the first accused Jan. 6 rioter to go on trial even as prosecutors announced they had expanded their inquiry by indicting a former leader of the Proud Boys, the far-right nationalist group that played a prominent role in the Capitol attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Watchdog Sees Cover-Up in Failure to Report Rikers Island Beatings
description: Louis Molina, the correction commissioner, responded to a recent New York Times report that found serious injuries to at least two detainees were not reported.
content: Louis A. Molina, the commissioner of the New York City Department of Correction, was harshly criticized on Tuesday by a jails oversight panel for his agency’s failure to document two brutal beatings that occurred on Rikers Island last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Taylor Tomlinson: A Comic With the Confidence of a Star
description: On her new Netflix special, “Look at You,” she demonstrates tight joke writing, carefully honed act-outs and a ruthless appetite for laughs.
content: The moment I knew that the stand-up comic Taylor Tomlinson was going to be a star was not after she made the precociously funny debut special, “Quarter-Life Crisis,” at the age of 25. Or her assured follow-up, “Look at You,” which premiered on Netflix this week. Or even after the news that she’s writing and starring in a movie about her own life (directed by Paul Weitz).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Apple Has to Try Hard Now
description: The tech giant used to give us only a few cool options. Now it has to work harder to win us over.
content: If Apple were a person, it wouldn’t be the type who runs to catch a flight and skids up to the gate in a flop sweat. Apple would saunter, calm and unhurried. Trying hard is not cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: Why Do Some People Never Get Covid?
description: Two years into the pandemic, a Covid mystery remains.
content: This article is part of Times Opinion’s reflection on the two year mark of the coronavirus pandemic. Read more in a note from Alexandra Sifferlin, Opinion’s health and science editor, in our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: Is This the End of the Trail Map?
description: At ski resorts around the country, the familiar paper map is disappearing, as mountains push skiers to use apps and other digital resources. But some skiers are pushing back.
content: At the end of this month, the artist James Niehues will be inducted into the U.S. Ski and Snowboard Hall of Fame, in recognition of the almost 200 trail maps he has painted over his 34-year career. Skiers from Mt. Bachelor, Ore., to Sunday River, Maine, and many points in between, have held his work in their hands as they try to find the easiest — or hardest — way down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: A Reading Crisis
description: Reading is fundamental, and about a third of young U.S. children are missing  benchmarks.
content: Since the beginning of the pandemic, Dana Goldstein, who covers education for The Times, has been hearing from parents concerned that their young children’s language development might have been hindered by masks in the classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Biden Bans Russian Oil
description: Plus South Korea is set to elect a new president and Afghan smugglers flourish.
content: President Biden announced a ban on imports of Russian oil and natural gas into the U.S., an escalation of economic penalties that could have consequences at home and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress Gives Final Approval to Make Lynching a Hate Crime
description: The bill’s unanimous passage in the Senate ended more than a century of failed attempts to explicitly criminalize lynching.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate unanimously approved a bill that would make lynching a federal hate crime, explicitly criminalizing a heinous act that has become a symbol of the nation’s history of racial violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Venezuela could be a fill-in for Russian oil, but critics fear aiding another strongman.
description: U.S. officials are reportedly considering easing sanctions on Venezuelan crude as oil prices have skyrocketed.
content: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela signaled on Monday a willingness to increase his country’s oil production if Russian supplies are shut out of the international market, as he described a meeting with American officials over the weekend as “respectful, cordial, very diplomatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Two Days of Russian News Coverage: An Alternate Reality of War
description: To watch news broadcasts of the fighting in Ukraine on the main state channels in Russia is to witness the extent of the Kremlin’s efforts to sanitize its war.
content: At a televised gathering with female pilots and crew members from Aeroflot, Russia’s flagship airline carrier, one participant asked President Vladimir V. Putin a question that was perfectly crafted to conform with new government rules for reporting on his invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bradford Pearson
title: Can A.I. Help Casinos Cut Down on Problem Gambling?
description: The opportunities seem endless. The reality is much more complicated.
content: This article is part of a new series on artificial intelligence’s potential to solve everyday problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: The Feel-Good Savings in Gov. Murphy’s Budget
description: The New Jersey governor's budget proposal is focused on providing savings for residents.
content: The New Jersey governor's budget proposal is focused on providing savings for residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle and John Otis
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Ukraine Refugees, State of the Union, ‘The Batman’
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In San Francisco, a Modern Gem With Colorful Surprises
description: When an interior designer and a software engineer set about renovating their new house, they had no idea what it would eventually involve.
content: When an interior designer and a software engineer set about renovating their new house, they had no idea what it would eventually involve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A New Direction in NoLIta
description: Once known for New Zealand cuisine, Musket Room is now open to influences from around the globe.
content: Once known for New Zealand cuisine, Musket Room is now open to influences from around the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: N.Y.C. Students Return to Class After School Mask Mandate Ends
description: New York City public-school children attended their first day of classes with masks optional for students in kindergarten and up.
content: New York City public-school children attended their first day of classes with masks optional for students in kindergarten and up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Praise for ‘Biden’s Courage’ in Imposing Oil Sanctions Against Russia
description: Readers hope that Americans and allies support the decision despite rising energy costs and call for conservation measures. Also: A faithful Catholic and his church.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Christie Brinkley, on Ukraine’s Nuclear Close Call
description: “This is a game of Russian roulette the world can’t afford to play!” the model and activist writes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 8, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 8, 2022.
content: An article on Monday about arms being sent to Ukraine from the United States and Europe misidentified the city that was overrun by Russian tanks in 1956. It was Budapest, not Prague.
source.name: The New York Times
